image.altText: a composite image of two women both standing outdoors on a street

items.synopsis: More than 100 people were displaced on Thursday when fire ravaged two buildings in Surry Hills, including the heritage-listed former RC Henderson hat factory.

title.children: Residents living near Sydney heritage building destroyed by fire uncertain when they can return home

image.altText: A man sits in a garden and looks to the side of the camera.

items.synopsis: Reforms in the wake of the child sexual abuse royal commission made it easier for victims to seek compensation, but now a fierce new battleground is emerging as some organisations at the centre of the claims push to have cases thrown out altogether.

title.children: The church knew Josh's abuser was a danger to kids. When Josh sued, they went after his family

image.altText: a policeman wearing glasses talking to the media

items.synopsis: On Friday night, a woman called triple-0 to report an assault. She was found dead on Saturday night in a unit in south-west Sydney, and a man charged with numerous DV offences.

title.children: Critical incident inquiry launched after woman found dead more than 20 hours after triple-0 call

image.altText: A person walks outside PWC.

items.synopsis: Under-fire accounting and consultancy firm PwC directs nine of its partners to take leave pending the outcome of an internal investigation into the leaking of confidential Australian government tax information.

title.children: PwC orders nine partners to go on leave amid tax scandal fallout

image.altText: A dad and daughter smile for a photo.

items.synopsis: A father is opening up about his daughter's death after she lost her life to anorexia nervosa. He says the illness took hold after a bullying incident.

title.children: Before her death at age 15, Liv pinpointed the moment her life spiralled. Her dad says he was blamed

image.altText: NSW rugby league star Latreell Mitchell runs in to score a try for the Blues in State of Origin.

items.synopsis: NSW has a selection headache for State of Origin, with Latrell Mitchell ruled out of the series opener after injuring his calf 48 hours before the game in Adelaide.

title.children: Blues star Latrell Mitchell ruled out of Origin I

image.altText: A man wearing a suit poses for a photo

items.synopsis: The race discrimination commissioner warns against making race the focus of debate on the Voice to Parliament, as opponents claim it will "re-racialise" the nation.

title.children: Voice opponents reassert body will 're-racialise' Australia, after warning from discrimination commissioner

image.altText: A map showing Melbourne and Sunbury

items.synopsis: A magnitude-3.8 earthquake in the Melbourne suburb of Sunbury strikes at a depth of 3 kilometres on Sunday night, according to Geoscience Australia, with a leading seismologist saying it could be the city's largest in 100 years.

title.children: Magnitude-3.8 quake in Melbourne's west felt from Bendigo to Hobart

image.altText: A smiling young man who is clean shaven

items.synopsis: Sydney man Mohammad Hashemi's cousin Majid Kazemi was executed after a "forced confession and sham trial". He says if the Australian government is serious about stopping the Islamic Republic's human rights abuses, it will cut ties with Iran and list their military arm as a terrorist organisation.

title.children: 'I swear to God I am innocent': Majid Kazemi begged for Australia's help before Iran's government executed him

image.altText: A screenshot of David Koch on Sunrise, with a banner announcing he's leaving the show

items.synopsis: Known by fans of the show as "Kochie", the veteran television presenter says it's time to bring in the "next generation" and is looking forward to working within business hours.

title.children: David Koch quits Sunrise hosting gig after two decades

image.altText: Artist rendition of a coronavirus

items.synopsis: The key to the mystery may lie in your genes.

title.children: It's been three years and I still haven't caught it – does that mean I'm immune to COVID-19?

image.altText: Pwc Logo

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police has reasserted its ability to effectively investigate a former member of PwC, as the firm completes millions of dollars worth of contracts working alongside AFP staff.

title.children: The AFP is investigating PwC — while the firm's staff work in its buildings

image.altText: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan holds a microphone waving at a crowd.

items.synopsis: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan will extend his increasingly authoritarian 20-year rule after beating rival Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu in the country's first-ever election run-off .

title.children: Opponent bemoans 'most unfair election in years' as Erdoğan claims victory in Türkiye's historic presidential runoff

image.altText: A man in a dark navy suit and pink tie speaks in parliament, with an Indigenous female minister sitting behind, watching on

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese will deliver the Lowitja O'Donoghue Oration in Adelaide on Monday night, using the speech to argue for the Yes campaign and contest arguments put up by opponents.

title.children: Anthony Albanese says No campaign is 'underestimating Australians' in lead-up to Voice referendum

image.altText: A close-up of a corporate pwc logo on a reflective glass building panel.

items.synopsis: After posting a weekly fall, the Australian share market has jumped at the start of trading, ahead of inflation data and the RBA governor speaking this week. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: PwC admits 'failure of leadership and governance' over tax scandal, ASX gains on US debt ceiling deal optimism

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market is off its early highs but is managing to hang onto most of its gains at lunchtime. The All Ordinaries and the ASX 200 remain more than 1 per cent higher, with some strong gains from the major miners, including BHP (+1.6%), as well as a good session for the banks, led by NAB (+1.6%). Real estate is the best performing sector, with Charter Hall Social Infrastructure REIT (+3.5%), HMC Capital (+3.4%) and Charter Hall Group (+3.3%) among the top movers. 162 of the top 200 stocks are in positive territory. The optimism on the local market and around the region has been fueled by the in-principle agreement reached to raise the US debt ceiling. But UBS chief US economist Jonathan Pingle says "it's not over, until it's over." Mr Pingle says the fact that 'X-date', or the date when the government will run out of measures to meet its debts and could potentially default, has been moved to June 5, from June 1, has substantially reduced the odds of the worst case scenario being realised. "The later X-date and agreement  being reached significantly lower the odds of negative market and economic impact."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX remains strongly higher mid-session

children.content: The local share market is off its early highs but is managing to hang onto most of its gains at lunchtime.
The
All Ordinaries and the ASX 200 remain more than 1 per cent higher
, with some strong gains from the major miners, including
BHP
(+1.6%), as well as a good session for the banks, led by
NAB
Real estate is the best performing sector, with
Charter Hall Social Infrastructure REIT
HMC Capital
Charter Hall Group
(+3.3%) among the top movers.

ASX 200 at lunchtime
(Refinitiv)
The optimism on the local market and around the region has been fueled by the in-principle agreement reached to raise the US debt ceiling.
But UBS chief US economist Jonathan Pingle says "it's not over, until it's over."

Mr Pingle says the fact that 'X-date', or the date when the government will run out of measures to meet its debts and could potentially default, has been moved to June 5, from June 1, has substantially reduced the odds of the worst case scenario being realised.
"The later X-date and agreement  being reached significantly lower the odds of negative market and economic impact."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC Australia has responded to calls for it to release the names of individuals who received emails outlining plans to use confidential government information about new tax laws to assist clients. In early May, Senate Estimates published internal emails concerning the tax leak, but names of recipients were redacted. In a statement and an open letter from acting chief executive Kristin Stubbins, the consulting firm said the assumption that all those who's names had been redacted were involved in wrongdoing was "incorrect". Here are the full comments from Ms Stubbins: "I fully understand and acknowledge the calls for PwC to release the names of the individuals in the emails released by the Senate on 2 May 2023. "There has been an assumption by some that all those whose names have been redacted must necessarily be involved in wrongdoing. That is incorrect. "Based on our ongoing investigation, w e believe that the vast majority of the recipients of these emails are neither responsible for, nor were knowingly involved in any confidentiality breach. "We have and will continue to take appropriate action against anyone who is found to have breached confidentiality or failed in their leadership duties." PwC did not release the redacted names.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC Australia denies all named on emails involved in wrongdoing

children.content: PwC Australia has responded to calls for it to release the names of individuals who received emails outlining plans to use confidential government information about new tax laws to assist clients.
In early May, Senate Estimates published internal emails concerning the tax leak, but names of recipients were redacted.

In a statement and an open letter from acting chief executive Kristin Stubbins, the consulting firm said the assumption that all those who's names had been redacted were involved in wrongdoing was "incorrect".
Here are the full comments from Ms Stubbins:
"I fully understand and acknowledge the calls for PwC to release the names of the individuals in the emails released by the Senate on 2 May 2023.
"There has been an assumption by some that all those whose names have been redacted must necessarily be involved in wrongdoing. That is incorrect.
"Based on our ongoing investigation, w
e believe that the vast majority of the recipients of these emails are neither responsible for, nor were knowingly involved in any confidentiality breach
"We have and will continue to take appropriate action against anyone who is found to have breached confidentiality or failed in their leadership duties."
PwC did not release the redacted names.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC Australia has announced further steps it is taking in response to the tax leak scandal, which is putting mounting pressure on the consultancy firm. In a statement released today, PwC said nine partners have been directed to go on leave, effective immediately. It is in the process 'ringfencing' the parts of the business that provide services to federal government departments and agencies, expected to be complete by the end of September. Two independent directors will also be appointed to its governance board, and it will publish the report of a previously-announced independent review in full. "It is now clear that when we learned of the confidentiality breach and related issues we failed to conduct an appropriate root cause investigation and thorough assessment of accountability for both the conduct at issue and the culture that allowed the underlying conduct to occur," the statement reads. "That was the result of a failure of leadership and governance ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC Australia admits 'failure of leadership and governance'

publish the report of a previously-announced independent review in full

"It is now clear that when we learned of the confidentiality breach and related issues we failed to conduct an appropriate root cause investigation and thorough assessment of accountability for both the conduct at issue and the culture that allowed the underlying conduct to occur," the statement reads.
"That was
the result of a failure of leadership and governance

image.altText: large logs in piles surrounding a yellow harvesting machine in a forest

items.synopsis: Conservation groups fear a further decline of the koala populations on the NSW north coast if logging doesn't stop within an area that could become protected habitat.

title.children: Conservationists push for logging ban in future koala park

image.altText: A man its in the driver's seat of a car smiling at a camera

items.synopsis: The adoption of electric vehicles continues to climb as sales in most states and territories double year-on-year. These people explain why they are, or are not, following the trend.

title.children: EVs sales still lag behind combustion engine cars. What are people debating?

image.altText: A young white woman with short brown hair and glasses. She's wearing a maroon jumper and holding a rubix cube

items.synopsis: Autism diagnoses are rising, but researchers say autistic girls and women are going under the radar, because diagnostic tools have been designed around how it manifests in males.

title.children: Heather was nearly 40 when diagnosed as autistic. She says the delay forced her into 'unhealthy' habits

image.altText: A burninig dual cab Toyota Land Cruiser in remote spinifex country near Balgo, Western Australia, 2023.

items.synopsis: Thought snakes and crocodiles were the main hazard in the outback? Think again. Motoring experts say after the big wet season cars are catching alight due to vegetation growth.

title.children: Outback travellers put on notice after increase in car fires

image.altText: two people smiling

items.synopsis: Amid soaring rents, some international students are forking out hundreds of dollars a week for hostels or cramped rooms a long way from where they go to school — but some are finding the generosity of locals is easing the pain.

title.children: 12,000km from home, Ezequiel couldn't find a rental until Te opened her doors

image.altText: A cast iron frypan with rounds of cheese, walnuts and fresh thyme baked on an open fire.

items.synopsis: Artisan cheesemakers say sales of gourmet cheese are defying cost-of-living pressures as more people enjoy little indulgences at home instead of eating out.

title.children: Why decadent gourmet cheese seems immune to cost-of-living pressures

image.altText: Luke Muscat smiling in front of a screen with a still from Fruit Ninja. Fruit being sliced.

items.synopsis: Fruit Ninja would become one of the most recognisable games of its era, downloaded more than 1 billion times and leaving an indelible mark on mobile gaming.

title.children: With his job on the brink, Luke pitched a game about cutting up fruit. It became a global phenomenon

image.altText: A firefighter sprays water from a hose on a pile of burning garbage on a street corner

items.synopsis: Waste crews are dealing with up to four fires every week in trucks and at facilities, an industry body spokesperson says.

title.children: Incorrectly disposed lithium batteries causing more garbage truck blazes, firefighters say

image.altText: A policewoman smiles in front of a blue sign on a brick wall reading Culgoa police station.

items.synopsis: At single-officer stations, cops have to strike a balance between police work and "being a friend" — and some like Annie Coobs wouldn't have it any other way.

title.children: As the only cop in town, Annie has 'no escape' from heartbreak. But she also finds joy

image.altText: A man holding a golden sceptre following by a long line of people.

items.synopsis: At least 19 opposition parties skipped the event, adding that Narendra Modi's decision to inaugurate the building was "a grave insult" to India's democracy.

title.children: Indian opposition compares new parliament inauguration to coronation, boycotts Modi's event

image.altText: A young woman cuddles a French Bulldog with a big smile on her face

items.synopsis: Since the death of their daughter nearly two years ago, Sophie Putland's family has worked tirelessly to advocate for change in the veterinary industry.

title.children: Sophie Putland's family say she loved being a vet, but the abuse she faced really affected her mental health

image.altText: A young man and woman sit on a couch.

items.synopsis: As a new report confirms Perth's status as one of the tightest rental markets in the country, an expert warns the situation is going to get worse before it gets better.

title.children: Rents soar by $178 per week in one Perth suburb as tenants feel the cost-of-living bite

image.altText: A composite image of Harry McKay, Simon Goodwin and Sam Mitchell

items.synopsis: It was a round of upsets across the AFL, one that has changed the shape of the season for some of the league's most fancied clubs. We digest the week that was.

title.children: AFL Round-Up: The tipsters' nightmare weekend shakes up the 2023 season

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe points as she looks up at a press conference

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe is considering abstaining from voting on legislation to enable the Voice referendum in the Senate but has ruled out supporting the No campaign.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe to lodge human rights complaint against Greens, may abstain from vote on Voice

image.altText: A model of a space craft lander on display

items.synopsis: Tokyo- based ispace made a failed attempt to complete the world's first commercial soft-landing on the Moon last month.

title.children: Japanese startup blames last minute changes for failed Moon landing

image.altText: Rescuers look out a large hole blown out from a brick building by a suicide drone.

items.synopsis: Kyiv officials say at least 40 drones attacked overnight and were shot down by air defence systems, with falling debris killing a man and injuring a woman.

title.children: Russia unleashes air strikes on Kyiv as the Ukrainian capital marks its birthday

image.altText: An Australian tennis player clenches his fist in celebration as he shouts with joy after winning a match at the French Open.

items.synopsis: Inspired play from Thanasi Kokkinakis, Storm Hunter and Jason Kubler gives Australia a flying start to the French Open with rousing first-round victories in Paris.

title.children: Aussie aces give Australia a golden start at French Open

image.altText: A banner that reads "WE ARE THE FAMOUS EFC" hangs in a packed football stadium

items.synopsis: The Premier League season is over, and the final places are decided, with three teams at the bottom of the ladder fighting for one remaining spot in next year's competition — two drop to the Championship after a final day of drama.

title.children: Dramatic final day of Premier League season settles final two relegated teams

image.altText: A leicester fan covers her face with her scarf

items.synopsis: Leicester City's Premier League title win in 2016 was a miracle of epic proportions. Their relegation this season saw that joyous fairytale turn into a nightmare, but it is not a huge surprise.

title.children: Leicester relegation caps rollercoaster era for former Premier League champions

image.altText: Lawyer in robes pouring sand into hands of two Indigenous men on beach with jetty in background

items.synopsis: A historic win allows the Indigenous nation to rise above the horrors of a dark colonial past on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula.

title.children: From near annihilation to empowering their destiny; this is the Nauo people's native title story
